When we read *Frankenstein* in English class, it’s easy to just think of it as an old horror story about a guy who makes a monster out of body parts. But if you actually look at what Mary Shelley was writing about, it’s crazy how much it relates to what’s happening right now with Artificial Intelligence. Even though the book was written over 200 years ago, it basically predicts all the stuff we’re worried about today regarding ChatGPT, robotics, and the future of technology.

The biggest connection between Victor Frankenstein and modern AI developers is the idea of playing God without thinking about the consequences. Victor is obsessed with his experiment, and he doesn’t really stop to think if he *should* create life, he just wants to see if he *can*. You see this same thing in the tech world today. Companies are racing to make the smartest AI possible, but they aren't always thinking about what happens if that AI becomes too powerful or if it starts replacing human jobs and creativity. Victor calls his creation a "catastrophe," which is exactly what some scientists are warning will happen if we don't put limits on AI.

Another big point is the idea of "The Uncanny Valley." In the book, Victor is disgusted by the creature because it looks almost human but not quite. It has yellow skin and "watery eyes," and it creeps him out so much that he runs away. This is exactly what people feel when they see AI-generated videos or robots that look too much like people. It’s that weird feeling that something is "fake" even if it’s acting real. Shelley shows that when we try to recreate humanity through technology, we often end up making something that feels wrong or scary to us.

The most important part of the book, though, is how Victor treats the creature. He abandons it as soon as it wakes up because he’s scared. Because the creature is lonely and rejected, it turns violent. This is a huge debate in AI right now: bias and "alignment." If we feed AI data that is mean or biased, the AI is going to act that way. If we don't "parent" the technology correctly, it could end up harming society. The monster isn't born evil; it becomes a monster because of how its creator treated it. If we create an AI that we can't control or that we treat poorly, we might be responsible for its "monstrous" actions later on.

In conclusion, *Frankenstein* isn't just a story about a zombie. It’s a warning. Mary Shelley is telling us that just because we have the power to create something new doesn't mean we’re ready for the responsibility that comes with it. Whether it’s a creature made of old parts or a computer program made of code, the creator is always responsible for what they bring into the world. If we don't learn from Victor’s mistakes, we might end up with our own version of a monster that we can't take back.

When you look at the news today, everyone loves to bring up George Orwell’s *1984*. People talk about "Big Brother" or government surveillance whenever they see a camera on a street corner. But if you actually look at how our society works right now, I think Aldous Huxley’s *Brave New World* is way closer to our reality. While Orwell’s world is scary because of pain and control, Huxley’s world is scary because of pleasure and distractions, which is exactly where we are heading.

In *1984*, the government stays in power through fear. There’s the Thought Police, torture in Room 101, and the constant threat of being "vaporized." It’s a very top-down, aggressive kind of dictatorship. While there are definitely countries that act like this today, it’s not really how most of the modern world functions. Most people wouldn't just sit there and let a giant screen scream at them every morning. We like our freedom too much—or at least, the *idea* of it.

That’s why *Brave New World* is more realistic. In Huxley’s book, the government doesn’t have to force people to obey because they’ve already convinced everyone to love their "servitude." Instead of banning books like they do in *1984*, the people in *Brave New World* just stop reading because they’re too busy with "feelies" (which are basically like 4D movies) and taking "soma," a drug that makes them happy all the time. 

This feels so much like our world today with social media and streaming services. We aren't being forced to stay off the streets by police; we’re staying inside because we’re addicted to TikTok or Netflix. We have an endless supply of entertainment that keeps us from thinking about real problems like climate change or politics. Just like the characters in Huxley's book who are obsessed with consumerism and instant gratification, we are constantly being told that buying things and staying "connected" online will make us happy.

Another big point is how information is handled. In *1984*, the government censors everything and changes history. But in *Brave New World*, there is so much information and "noise" that the truth just gets drowned out. This is exactly what’s happening with the internet. We aren't lacking information; we have too much of it, and a lot of it is fake or just meant to distract us. We’re losing our ability to focus on what actually matters because we’re constantly being hit with notifications.

In conclusion, while *1984* is a great warning about what happens when a government gets too much power, *Brave New World* is a more accurate map of where we are right now. We aren't being oppressed by a dictator who hates us; we’re being controlled by a system that knows exactly how to keep us entertained and distracted. We aren't living in a world of pain; we're living in a world of "likes" and distractions, which is a lot harder to fight against.

When most people think of Walt Whitman, they think of *Leaves of Grass* and him shouting his "barbaric yawp" over the roofs of the world. But if you really look at his work, there’s a massive shift between his early stuff and what he wrote after 1861. The Civil War didn't just change America; it completely changed how Whitman wrote. Before the war, he was all about the individual and this almost cocky optimism, but after seeing the horrors of the hospitals, his poetry became way more grounded, gritty, and honestly, pretty sad.

Whitman wasn't a soldier, but he was right in the middle of the action as a volunteer nurse in Washington, D.C. He spent years visiting thousands of wounded soldiers, bringing them snacks, writing letters for them, and just sitting with them while they died. This experience shows up most clearly in his collection *Drum-Taps*. In the poem "The Wound-Dresser," he doesn't talk about glory or flags or "winning." Instead, he writes about the "clotted rags" and the "refuse" of the hospital. He describes a soldier with a "crush’d head" and another with a "stump of the arm." As a high schooler reading this, it’s honestly kind of gross, but that’s the point. Whitman wanted people to see that war isn't a parade; it’s blood and pain.

Another way the war influenced him was how he viewed democracy. Before the war, democracy was kind of an abstract idea for him—it was just about everyone being free and happy. But after seeing men from the North and the South dying in the same hospital wards, he started to see democracy as something that required sacrifice. In "Vigil Strange I Kept on the Field One Night," he writes about a soldier staying with a dead comrade until sunrise. It’s a really quiet, intimate poem. It shows that the "union" wasn't just a political thing for Whitman anymore; it was a spiritual connection between people that even death couldn't break.

Then there’s his obsession with Abraham Lincoln. Whitman saw Lincoln as the ultimate symbol of the American spirit. When Lincoln was assassinated, Whitman was devastated, and it led to some of his most famous poems, like "O Captain! My Captain!" and "When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d." "O Captain!" is actually weird because it rhymes and has a steady beat, which isn't usually Whitman’s style. It shows how the grief of the war made him reach for more traditional forms to express his sadness. 

In conclusion, the Civil War took Whitman from being a poet of "self" to being a poet of the nation. He stopped just celebrating himself and started mourning for everyone. His time in the hospitals forced him to look at the dark side of life, and his poetry became much more mature because of it. Without the war, Whitman might have stayed just a guy writing about grass, but the war turned him into the "Good Gray Poet" who captured the soul of a broken country.

When you first read Rumi, it’s easy to think he’s just writing about romance or being in love. But if you look closer at his background as a Sufi mystic, you realize that his poems aren't really about human dating—they’re about a soul trying to find its way back to God. Rumi wasn’t just a poet; he was a teacher and a leader in the Sufi tradition of Islam, and his most famous work, the *Masnavi*, is basically a guidebook for how to connect with the divine.

To understand Rumi, you have to understand Sufism. Sufism is the mystical side of Islam that focuses on the "inner" journey. While some parts of religion focus a lot on rules and laws, Sufis focus on the heart. They believe that humans are separated from God and that our whole purpose in life is to close that gap. In the *Masnavi*, Rumi uses a really famous metaphor about a reed flute. He says the flute makes a sad, crying sound because it was cut away from the reed bed where it belongs. This is basically a metaphor for us—humans are the flutes, and we’re "singing" or longing to go back to our source, which is God.

One of the big themes in Rumi’s work is the idea of "killing the ego." In Sufism, the ego (or the *nafs*) is like a veil that keeps you from seeing the truth. Rumi writes a lot about how we get distracted by money, fame, or just our own selfishness. He uses stories in the *Masnavi*—some of them are actually kind of funny or weird—to show how people get stuck in their own heads. He teaches that you have to let go of your "self" to be filled with God’s love. It’s kind of like how a drop of water disappears when it falls into the ocean; it doesn’t stop existing, it just becomes part of something way bigger.

Another huge part of his work is the concept of "Divine Love." For Rumi, God isn’t some scary judge in the sky; God is the "Beloved." This is why his poems sound so passionate. He uses the language of longing and intoxication (like being drunk on love) to describe what it feels like to pray or meditate. This reflects the Islamic mystical tradition of *Dhikr*, which is the constant remembrance of God. Rumi believed that everything in the universe—the stars, the trees, and people—is constantly "dancing" or revolving around God. This is actually where the "Whirling Dervishes" came from; his followers literally started dancing to reach a state of religious ecstasy.

In conclusion, Rumi’s poetry isn't just "deep" quotes for Instagram; it’s a reflection of his life as a Sufi. Through the *Masnavi*, he shows that the path to God is through the heart and through love rather than just following rituals. He reminds his readers that even though we feel lonely or "cut off" like the reed flute, we are actually connected to something divine if we just learn how to look inward.

In my history and lit classes, we talk a lot about Niccolò Machiavelli’s *The Prince* like it’s this "evil handbook" for dictators. When you first read it, it definitely feels that way. He says stuff like "it is better to be feared than loved" and basically tells leaders that it’s okay to lie and kill people if it keeps the state stable. But the more I think about it, the more I wonder if he was actually being serious. Is *The Prince* a real guide for tyrants, or is it actually a secret satire meant to warn people about how bad rulers act?

The most common argument is that it’s a genuine guide. At the time, Italy was a total mess—it was divided into small city-states that were always fighting, and foreign countries like France and Spain were constantly invading. Machiavelli had a job in the government of Florence, but he lost it when the Medici family took over. He was even tortured. Some people think he wrote the book as a "job application" to the Medicis to show them he knew how politics worked and to help them unite Italy. If you look at it that way, his advice to be "the lion and the fox" makes sense because he just wanted a strong leader to fix the country, even if that leader had to be a jerk.

However, there’s a lot of evidence that it might be satire. First of all, Machiavelli was a huge supporter of republics (where people have a say) in his other writings, like *The Discourses on Livy*. It seems weird that a guy who loved liberty would suddenly write a book praising cold-blooded dictators. Some scholars, like Jean-Jacques Rousseau, argued that *The Prince* was actually a "handbook for Republicans." By "teaching" a prince how to be a tyrant, Machiavelli was actually exposing all the dirty tricks that rulers use. It’s like he was shouting to the regular people, "Hey, look! This is what your leaders are doing behind your back!"

Also, some of the advice is so extreme it almost feels like a joke. He tells rulers that if they take over a new city, they should just destroy it entirely so the people don’t rebel. He also says a prince should pretend to be religious and kind while being the opposite. If a prince actually followed every single piece of advice in the book, he would probably end up being hated by everyone, which Machiavelli himself says is the one thing a ruler should avoid.

In my opinion, I think it’s probably a bit of both. I don’t think it’s a "funny" satire like something on *Saturday Night Live*, but I do think it’s cynical. Machiavelli was probably frustrated with how corrupt politics were. By writing *The Prince*, he was showing the world that politics isn’t about being a "good person" in a Sunday school way—it’s about power. Whether he wanted to help a tyrant or expose one, the book works because it’s so honest about how dark humans can be. Even if he didn't mean it as a joke, it serves as a warning for us today to watch out for leaders who follow his "rules."

Mary Shelley’s *Frankenstein* still matters a lot in modern debates about artificial intelligence because it’s basically a story about what happens when humans create something powerful without thinking through the consequences. Even though Shelley wrote it in the early 1800s, the book feels weirdly current when people argue about AI safety, responsibility, and whether we should build certain technologies just because we can.

One of the biggest connections to AI is Victor Frankenstein’s attitude toward creation. Victor is obsessed with the idea of making life, but he treats the act like a personal achievement instead of a moral responsibility. He talks about glory and discovery, and once the Creature is alive, Victor immediately panics and abandons it. That part feels like a warning about how tech companies or researchers sometimes act with AI: they rush to build the “next big thing,” but they don’t always plan for what happens after it’s released into the world. In modern AI debates, people bring up “alignment” and “safety,” which is basically making sure AI systems do what we want and don’t cause harm. Victor’s problem is that he never even tries to “align” his creation with any kind of care, values, or guidance. He just leaves it alone, and then acts shocked when it goes badly.

The Creature itself is also important to this discussion because Shelley makes it clear that the Creature isn’t born evil. It learns by watching humans, reading, and trying to connect. It becomes violent after it’s repeatedly rejected and treated like a monster. That’s relevant to AI because a lot of AI systems learn from human data, and that data can be biased, cruel, or unfair. In the same way the Creature learns what humanity is like through other people’s actions, AI “learns” patterns from what we’ve put online. If the world it learns from is full of stereotypes, hate, or misinformation, then the AI can reflect that back. Shelley shows that a creator can’t just blame the creation and pretend they had nothing to do with the outcome.

Another point is how *Frankenstein* shows the danger of refusing accountability. Victor keeps his experiment secret and isolates himself while making the Creature, which parallels how some AI development happens behind closed doors, controlled by a small group with a lot of power. When things start going wrong, Victor doesn’t tell people the truth, even when it could save lives. This connects to current debates about transparency and regulation. If AI tools are going to affect everyone—jobs, education, policing, warfare—then the “Victors” of the world shouldn’t get to hide their work and then act helpless when harm happens.

Finally, Shelley uses the framing of multiple narrators (Walton, Victor, and the Creature) to make readers question who gets to tell the story. That matters today because AI isn’t just a technical topic; it’s also about whose voices matter in decisions. The people most affected by AI systems often aren’t the ones building them. *Frankenstein* pushes us to listen to the “Creature” side too, meaning the people impacted by technology, not just the inventors celebrating it.

Overall, *Frankenstein* stays relevant because it isn’t only about a monster—it’s about creators, consequences, and the responsibilities that come with making something you can’t fully control. That’s basically the core of the AI debate right now.

When people talk about dystopias, *1984* by George Orwell and *Brave New World* by Aldous Huxley usually come up first. Both books show societies where freedom is basically gone, but they get there in different ways. Orwell imagines a world ruled through fear, constant surveillance, and punishment. Huxley imagines a world where people are controlled through comfort, entertainment, and being trained from birth to never want anything different. Between the two, I think *Brave New World* is more likely to become true, mostly because a lot of modern life already runs on distraction and “easy happiness,” and people often give up privacy and independence without being forced.

In *1984*, the government has to work really hard to keep control. The Party uses telescreens to watch everyone, rewrites history, and punishes people brutally. It’s control through pain. The citizens don’t trust each other, even families. Winston’s whole life is shaped by fear—fear of saying the wrong thing, fear of being caught thinking the wrong thought, fear of being erased. This kind of dystopia depends on an all-powerful government that is willing to use violence openly and constantly. While some real countries do have heavy surveillance and censorship, the full *1984* setup seems difficult to keep stable everywhere. People resist when they’re pushed too hard, and fear-based systems create a lot of tension.

*Brave New World* feels more realistic because it doesn’t need as much obvious force. In Huxley’s society, people are controlled by pleasure. They take soma to avoid sadness, they’re surrounded by entertainment, and they’re conditioned to love their social role. The smartest move the World State makes is that it doesn’t just stop rebellion—it makes rebellion seem pointless. If everyone is comfortable, numb, and constantly distracted, they don’t think to fight for freedom. That hits close to home because modern society already has versions of soma (not literally, but in the form of endless scrolling, streaming, online shopping, and other quick dopamine hits). We don’t need a dictator to make us check our phones 100 times a day. We just do.

Also, *Brave New World* is tied to technology and consumerism, which are only getting bigger. Companies and apps are designed to keep our attention, and a lot of people are fine trading privacy for convenience. That’s not exactly the same as Orwell’s government spying, but the result can be similar: someone is always watching, collecting data, and shaping what you see. Huxley’s world also includes genetic engineering and “designed” people. That part used to seem far-fetched, but now we have things like IVF, gene editing discussions, and algorithms predicting behavior. Even if we never fully create caste-based humans, the idea of people being shaped and sorted by systems from birth doesn’t feel impossible.

That said, I don’t think it’s an either/or situation. Parts of *1984* are happening too: misinformation, propaganda, and attempts to rewrite reality are real problems. But overall, the path we’re already on looks more like Huxley’s. It’s easier to control people when they’re entertained and comfortable than when they’re terrified all the time.

So if I had to choose, *Brave New World* seems more likely because it’s the dystopia people might accept willingly. It warns that losing freedom doesn’t always happen because someone takes it by force—sometimes it happens because people stop

Walt Whitman is often remembered as the poet of big, hopeful ideas about America, but his writing changed a lot during and after the Civil War. Before the war, in *Leaves of Grass*, Whitman mostly celebrated everyday people, the body, nature, and democracy in this confident, almost fearless way. Once he experienced the war up close, his poetry became more serious and focused on suffering, death, and the cost of keeping the country together. His time in hospitals and his witness to real violence didn’t make him stop believing in America, but it definitely reshaped the tone and the subjects of his poems.

Whitman didn’t fight as a soldier, but the war still became personal for him. In 1862 he went to Washington, D.C. after hearing his brother might be wounded. While he was there, he started visiting military hospitals and ended up staying for years, helping injured soldiers by bringing food, writing letters, and just sitting with them. This experience matters because Whitman wasn’t writing about the war from far away, like it was just a headline. He was looking directly at “ordinary” young men who were missing limbs, dying of infection, or dealing with trauma. That closeness shows up in how detailed and human his war poems feel.

One major way the war influenced his poetry is that he began to focus less on grand speeches and more on individual lives. In poems from *Drum-Taps* (his Civil War collection), Whitman often zooms in on one scene or one person to show the meaning of the war. For example, in “The Wound-Dresser,” the speaker describes going from bed to bed caring for soldiers, noticing their wounds and trying to comfort them. The point isn’t to glorify battle. Instead, Whitman shows the war as intimate and painful, almost like the whole country is one giant hospital. The repeated attention to bodies—bandages, blood, weakness—connects to Whitman’s earlier fascination with the body, but now it’s the body broken by history, not just celebrated.

The war also changed Whitman’s tone. Earlier Whitman can sound overly confident, like America is unstoppable. After the war begins, his writing still has hope, but it’s mixed with grief. The best example is “O Captain! My Captain!,” written after Lincoln’s assassination. Unlike Whitman’s usual free verse style, this poem is tight, rhythmic, and emotional, almost like a song people could recite at a funeral. The speaker is proud that the “ship” (the nation) has made it through the storm, but he can’t enjoy the victory because the captain is dead. That combination of triumph and loss captures how the war made national unity feel expensive and fragile.

Finally, Whitman’s war experience deepened his ideas about democracy. In the hospitals, he saw soldiers from different states, classes, and backgrounds suffering in the same rooms. That made his belief in “the people” more grounded and real. He wasn’t just praising Americans in theory; he was caring for them in crisis. His poems start to suggest that democracy isn’t only about celebrating freedom, but also about responsibility—showing up for others when things fall apart.

Overall, Whitman’s Civil War experience influenced his poetry by making it more personal, mournful, and realistic. He still tried to speak for the whole nation, but after the war, he spoke as someone who had held the nation’s pain in his hands. The Civil War didn’t erase Whitman’s hope; it forced him to earn it.

Jalal al-Din Rumi is often introduced as a “love poet,” but that label doesn’t really explain who he was or why his writing matters. Rumi’s role was basically that of a Sufi mystic: someone inside the Islamic tradition who focused on experiencing God directly through love, self-discipline, and spiritual practice. When you read poems from Rumi or look at his longer work, the *Masnavi*, you can see that he isn’t just writing pretty lines about romance. He’s trying to guide people toward a deeper inner life that fits into Islamic mystical tradition, especially the Sufi idea that the heart can be trained to recognize God.

Sufism is sometimes described as the “inner” side of Islam. It doesn’t replace the Qur’an or basic religious practices; instead, it emphasizes meaning behind them. Rumi fits into that because he often takes familiar Islamic ideas—like repentance, prayer, humility, and trust in God—and turns them into vivid stories or images that make the spiritual struggle feel real. In the *Masnavi*, he uses teaching tales, jokes, and dramatic scenes to show how people get stuck in ego, pride, or shallow thinking. The point is almost always transformation: moving from the self’s small desires toward something larger and purer.

A key part of Rumi’s identity as a mystic is the idea of longing. In Sufi writing, longing isn’t just sadness—it’s the soul remembering that it came from God and wanting to return. Rumi uses this theme constantly. The famous image of the reed flute (often used to open discussions of the *Masnavi*) is about separation and yearning: the reed has been cut from the reed bed, so it “cries” in music. That becomes a symbol for the human soul. This reflects Islamic mystical tradition because Sufis often talk about the world as a temporary place and God as the true home, so the pain of longing becomes a spiritual clue instead of something meaningless.

Another way the *Masnavi* reflects Sufi tradition is how it teaches through paradox and metaphor. Rumi will say things that sound confusing at first, like losing yourself to find yourself, or becoming “nothing” to become close to God. That matches the Sufi idea of *fana* (the fading of the ego) and *baqa* (living in God). Even if Rumi doesn’t always use those exact terms, the direction of his message points there: the self-centered “I” has to shrink so the soul can open. His stories often show characters who think they are wise but are really trapped by their own pride. That’s not just moral advice; it’s spiritual diagnosis.

Rumi also reflects Islamic tradition because he constantly alludes to Qur’anic themes, prophets, and religious lessons, but he presents them in a personal and emotional way. He’s not writing a law book or a theology textbook. He’s trying to awaken the reader. In that sense, the *Masnavi* works like a guide for spiritual growth, similar to how other Sufi teachers wrote manuals for the heart. Rumi’s special talent is that he does it with imagination—turning spiritual concepts into scenes you can picture and feel.

Overall, Rumi’s role as a Sufi mystic shapes everything he writes. The *Masnavi* isn’t just literature; it’s meant to lead people toward God through stories of love, loss, and self-discovery. His poems reflect Islamic mystical tradition by focusing on inner change, devotion, and the idea that behind everyday life there is a deeper reality calling the soul back home.

Niccolò Machiavelli’s *The Prince* is one of those books that almost dares you to decide what it “really” is. On the surface, it looks like a straightforward handbook for rulers, including the kind of rulers we’d call tyrants. But the more you read it, the more it also feels like Machiavelli might be exposing how ugly power can get when a leader cares more about staying in control than being morally good. In my opinion, *The Prince* works as a genuine guide to power, but it also doubles as a critique by making that guide so blunt and uncomfortable that readers can’t ignore the cost.

First, there’s a lot of evidence that Machiavelli is seriously trying to teach rulers how to keep power. He’s not shy about giving advice that sounds ruthless. One of the most famous ideas is that it’s safer for a prince to be feared than loved, if he can’t be both. That’s not written like a joke; he carefully explains why fear is more reliable than love, since love depends on people’s loyalty, and loyalty can change when things get hard. He also talks about using cruelty “well,” meaning quickly and all at once, so the prince can stabilize the state and then stop. That kind of detail sounds like someone giving real strategic advice, not just making fun of tyrants.

Machiavelli also spends a lot of time on appearances. He argues that a prince doesn’t have to actually be virtuous, but he should look virtuous. This is where the book starts to feel kind of dark, because it treats morality like a costume. The “fox and lion” idea fits here too: the prince must be strong like a lion but sneaky like a fox. Again, these sections read like a cold, realistic manual for surviving politics, especially in violent times. If Machiavelli wanted to warn people away from tyranny, why write such usable instructions?

On the other hand, the book can also be read as a critique because of how extreme and direct the advice is. Machiavelli doesn’t soften anything. When he says a prince must “learn how not to be good,” it feels like he’s purposely stripping away the comforting stories people tell about leaders being noble or chosen by God. In a weird way, his honesty makes tyranny look worse, not better. If you follow his logic all the way through, leadership becomes a constant cycle of manipulation, force, and image management. Even if Machiavelli is “helping” a prince, he’s also showing regular readers what’s happening behind the curtain.

The context matters too. Machiavelli had connections to the Florentine republic and got pushed out when the Medici came back. He dedicates *The Prince* to a Medici, which could mean he’s trying to get a job and prove he’s useful. But that also opens the door to another interpretation: he may be writing something that sounds loyal while actually revealing the tactics of authoritarian rule. Plus, compared with his other writing (like *Discourses on Livy*, where he seems more pro-republic), it’s hard not to suspect there’s more going on than simple praise for strongmen.

So is it a genuine guide or a satirical critique? I think it’s both. It’s a real guide in the sense that the strategies are practical and clearly explained. But it’s also a critique because the “how-to
